metadata.subject: European Equity Strategy: 2017 year ahead – Refining the reflation rotation
metadata.sender: Ronan Carr, James Barty, Tommy Ricketts

financial_entities: Bank of America Merrill Lynch International Limited

relationships.description: Leader of the anti-EU Front National party

analysis.purpose: To provide investment strategy and sector allocation recommendations for European equities in 2017 based on economic and political analysis
analysis.significance: Comprehensive market analysis from a major financial institution during a period of significant political and economic uncertainty in Europe

notable_quotes: A Marine Le Pen victory could bring into question both the future of the EU and also the euro, should the polls be close it could make the uncertainty and market moves around Brexit look like a walk in the park.
The lesson of that is that themes are great, but when the facts change strategists and investors have to change their minds.
We think investors will demand a higher risk premium until the French Elections in May 2017 given the likelihood that Marine Le Pen will make to the second round of voting.

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this financial research document

illegal_activity.description: Document contains standard financial analysis and market commentary with no evidence of illegal activity

public_knowledge.context: Financial research reports from major institutions are typically distributed to clients and may become publicly available. The political and economic analysis would be of interest to financial media.

analysis.summary: This Bank of America Merrill Lynch research report provides a comprehensive analysis of European equity strategy for 2017, focusing on the reflation rotation theme, political risks from upcoming European elections, and sector allocation recommendations with overweight positions in Oil, Healthcare, Utilities, and Media while underweighting UK domestic exposure like Retail and Travel sectors.
